prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the person who wrote this is in the wrong. Let's break down the situation. They live with their girlfriend, and he's been paying all the bills because she only works part-time. Recently, there was a $40 takeout incident where he asked her to pay for it because he left his wallet. She didn't like that, and he's been upset about it. Now he's considering making her pay some bills because of this one incident.

First, I should consider the dynamics of their relationship. He's always covered everything, which might be fine if they both agreed to it. But when he asked her to pay for a small amount, her reaction was negative. He feels like she should start contributing more, even if she can't handle a lot. The question is whether he's in the wrong for making her pay some bills over this one incident.

From his perspective, he's been handling all the expenses, which could be a point of imbalance. If she's working part-time, maybe she has some income to contribute, even if it's small. But the problem here is that he's using a single $40 incident as a catalyst to change the financial arrangement. That might be a bit unfair because one instance doesn't necessarily mean she's not willing to contribute. Maybe she was just caught off guard or felt it was unfair to be asked to pay for something he should have handled.

Also, communication is key. If he hasn't discussed the financial expectations before, suddenly changing the rules could be seen as unfair. The girlfriend might not have realized that he expected her to contribute more, so this incident is the first time he's brought it up. That could lead to resentment. 

On the other hand, if he's been covering all expenses and feels it's time for her to start helping, even if it's a small amount, it's reasonable. But the way he's approaching it—because of one incident—might not be fair. It's important to talk about financial responsibilities in a relationship and come to an agreement together, rather than using a single event as a justification for change.

So, is he in the wrong? Well, he's not entirely wrong in wanting a more balanced approach, but the timing and reason (a single incident) might be. He should have had that conversation before, not just react to this takeout incident. His approach could be seen as unfair because it's not based on a prior discussion but rather a single, minor event. Therefore, he might be in the wrong for making the change abruptly over something that's not a big expense. The answer might be A, but I need to make sure.
